    <item>
      <title>Timm Klose gives Norwich a point in dramatic finish against Ipswich</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/norwich-city-ipswich-town-championship-match-report</link>
      <description><p>It was like the harvest festival and the summer equinox came all at once. A see-saw end to the Old Farm derby sent first one set of fans then the other into delirium as two late goals meant the spoils were shared between Norwich and Ipswich.</p><p>First Luke Chambers for Ipswich then, in the final seconds of added time, Timm Klose for Norwich scored thumping headers in a contest that swung first one way then the other and ultimately ended in a draw. It also means City remain unbeaten in 10 derby matches.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/norwich-city-ipswich-town-championship-match-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Hakan Sukur – Turkey’s fallen hero who can never return home</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/hakan-sukur-turkey-fallen-hero-exile</link>
      <description>Scorer of the fastest World Cup goal had Turkey’s president as a wedding guest but now lives in enforced exile in the US<p>There is a photograph, famous in Turkey, taken at the wedding of one of the nation’s greatest footballers, a Uefa Cup winner who played in a World Cup semi-final. In the picture, Hakan Sukur is next to two witnesses, the nation’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and the cleric Fethullah Gulen. A wedding is supposed to be one of the highlights in a man’s life but it did not work out like that for Sukur.</p><p>The woman he married that day is dead, Sukur’s father has been imprisoned and the player capped 112 times by Turkey finds himself in exile. Should he ever return to his native land he would face charges of insulting the president and rebelling against the government. Life imprisonment would be certain and he could even face the death penalty. He will never see his father again, all the adulation he once had is lost. Sukur has lost his country.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/hakan-sukur-turkey-fallen-hero-exile">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>José Mourinho: VAR ‘went against original protocol’ to rule out Mata goal</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/var-jose-mourinho-manchester-united-fa-cup-huddersfield</link>
      <description>• Video official was deployed to judge Juan Mata offside<br />• Lines on the screen appeared to be wavy and uneven<p>José Mourinho said that the use of VAR to disallow a Juan Mata goal in Manchester United’s 2-0 FA Cup fifth round win over Hudderfield Town “went against the original protocol” of the system and that football is “ too beautiful to be spoiled by something not perfect.”</p><p>Mata was initially adjudged to have beaten the offside trap to score in the first-half, but the decision was referred to the video referee and he was deemed to be beyond the last man - or, at least, his knee was slightly beyond the offside line.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/var-jose-mourinho-manchester-united-fa-cup-huddersfield">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Valverde’s Barcelona balancing act turns crisis talk to treble talk</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/ernesto-valverde-barcelona-crisis-treble-chelsea-champions-league</link>
      <description>The coach used Neymar’s exit as a chance to reboot the faltering giants as Chelsea may find out on Tuesday<p>Sometimes football really is life. On Tuesday Barcelona face Chelsea in the Champions League at Stamford Bridge where in 2009 Andrés Iniesta scored a last-minute goal that he still watches occasionally. “It’s a moment that is always there, forever,” he says. For some fans, reminded of it daily, that is especially true. According to a spokeswoman for the maternity ward at the Quirón hospital in Catalonia, his goal didn’t only take Barça to the final, it provoked a spike in the birth rate. “I’m going to have to get more staff in if they keep winning titles,” Mercedes Rodríguez joked.</p><p>Nine months after Iniesta’s goal, Rodríguez noted that births were up from nine or 10 a day to 14 or 15 in her hospital alone. “People asked if there had been a full moon or something,” she said. Some reports claimed a 45% increase, which seemed unlikely, so it was tested. A study in the British Medical Journal admitted to potential “bias owing to the effects of the adjacent jubilation” of Barcelona-supporting researchers and was quick to note that they “didn’t contribute to the observed effect”, but tentatively concluded that it was plausible to talk of a 16% rise. More research, though, was needed.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/ernesto-valverde-barcelona-crisis-treble-chelsea-champions-league">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ian Henderson: ‘In Turkey I didn’t get paid. I was acting as my own lawyer’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/ian-henderson-rochdale-spurs-fa-cup</link>
      <description><p>Bad luck and instability almost led Rochdale’s captain to quit football. Now he has found a happy place and has Spurs in his sights</p><p>Ian Henderson had reached a crossroads in his life when the invitation came to train with Rochdale five years ago. He had just been released by Colchester United and the realities of life as a professional footballer were not turning out to be what he had envisaged when he was coming through the youth system at Norwich City. Being offered bags of cash by persons unknown to leave the Turkish club Ankaragucu in 2009 had seen to that.</p><p>Clubless and careerless, or so he thought, the striker considered turning his back on football to become an orthodontist. Today, as captain of Rochdale in the FA Cup fifth round, it is only the lilywhites of Tottenham Hotspur that concern him. Today he will feel indebted to the manager, Keith Hill, for providing the right direction.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/ian-henderson-rochdale-spurs-fa-cup">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/football/fa-cup">FA Cup</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/football/rochdale">Rochdale</category>

      <title>Antonio Conte says Chelsea need ‘perfect game’ to beat Barcelona</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/antonio-conte-chelsea-perfect-game-barcelona-champions-league</link>
      <description>• Manager seeks to exploit ‘weaknesses without the ball’ <br />• Cesc Fàbregas to forget old friendships on pitch<p>Antonio Conte insists Barcelona are not infallible and that it would be dangerous for his rejuvenated team to focus solely on stopping Lionel Messi – who has never scored against Chelsea – when the two sides meet at Stamford Bridge on Tuesday evening.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2018/feb/16/eden-hazard-chelsea-barcelona-messi-champions-league" title="">Chelsea host Ernesto Valverde’s side</a> in the first leg of the Champions League last-16 for the first time since beating the La Liga leaders in the semi-finals of the competition in 2012, the same year they went on to lift the trophy after edging out Bayern Munich on penalties.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/antonio-conte-chelsea-perfect-game-barcelona-champions-league">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jupp Heynckes, the safe pair of hands Bayern Munich can’t bear to lose</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/jupp-heynckes-bayern-munich-safe-pair-of-hands-desperate-to-stay</link>
      <description>Instead of just minding the shop in his fourth stint as manager the man from Mönchengladbach is being begged to stay<p>Jupp Heynckes has a proud record to protect. In each of the three seasons he has coached a team in the Champions League, they have reached the final. And should Bayern Munich win this season’s competition – a quest that continues with <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/13/champions-league-last-16-fans-preview" title="">Tuesday’s first-leg meeting with Beskitas</a> – he is likely to repeat what followed his two victories: swiftly departing the club he guided to Europe’s premier prize.</p><p>In 1998, Real Madrid sacked him despite a first European Cup in 32 years, while in 2013 Bayern had already agreed to bring Pep Guardiola to Bavaria. Having beaten Borussia Dortmund 2-1 at Wembley, Heynckes somewhat reluctantly entered a retirement that lasted until September’s return as a sprightly 72-year-old.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/jupp-heynckes-bayern-munich-safe-pair-of-hands-desperate-to-stay">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/jess-fishlock-inspires-melbourne-city-to-third-w-league-title</link>
      <description><ul><li>Sydney FC 0-2 Melbourne City at Allianz Stadium</li><li>Wales international scores one and has a hand in another</li></ul><p>Three years, three titles. Melbourne City’s domination of the W-League shows no signs of abating after Jess Fishlock inspired the club to a third championship in the three years of their existence in a 2-0 win over Sydney FC at Allianz Stadium.</p><p>Welsh international Fishlock scored one and played an integral part in the other – netted by another import, Jodie Taylor – as City, who finished the regular season in fourth place on the ladder, proved they know what it takes to win when it really matters. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/jess-fishlock-inspires-melbourne-city-to-third-w-league-title">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>FA Cup quarter-final draw - Leicester to face Chelsea, Man Utd draw Brighton</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/feb/17/fa-cup-quarter-final-draw-live</link>
      <description><p>Leicester will host Chelsea in the last eight of the FA Cup, while Brighton will face Manchester United and Sheffield Wednesday could host Tottenham</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2018-02-17T21:35:36.575Z">9.35pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Manchester United were drawn at home to Brighton in an FA Cup quarter-final draw which saw all the big guns avoid each other on Saturday evening. </p><p>Jose Mourinho’s men learned they would face the Seagulls shortly after sealing their place in the last eight with a <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/huddersfield-manchester-united-fa-cup-match-report">2-0 fifth-round win at Huddersfield</a> thanks to Romelu Lukaku’s brace. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2018-02-17T20:10:24.616Z">8.10pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p><strong>If everything goes with the form book</strong> then we should be looking at Chelsea, Manchester United, Manchester City and Spurs in the semi-final. The FA Cup is rarely that simple, so we should end up with an upset or two, if we are lucky.</p><p>We do get a repeat of the 1983 FA Cup final when Manchester United host Brighton but other than that it looks like it could be a quiet round. Only time will tell, though.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/feb/17/fa-cup-quarter-final-draw-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>‘It isn’t easy admitting you were one of Barry Bennell’s boys’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/16/crewe-barry-bennell-micky-fallon</link>
      <description><p>Micky Fallon, one of the former players Bennell has been convicted of abusing, reveals the horrors he endured and asks how Crewe did not realise the coach was a risk when opponents called them ‘The paedophile lads’</p><p>There is a scar on my cheek that will always be there to remind me about my childhood. Over the years, I’ve got used to it being there, I suppose. But whenever anyone asked how I got that scar I would just say as little as possible and move on swiftly. It was easier that way because, if I said what really happened, that would mean explaining I used to be at Crewe Alexandra. I knew if I said those words I’d have to get my head in a space that took me back to that football club. And from the age of 18, since the day I left that club, I’d shut down that part of my life off and, until now, never wanted to revisit it.</p><p>The truth is not easy for me to explain. For 32 years, I denied everything. I read <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/16/andy-woodward">the interview with Andy Woodward</a> that opened all this up and for a while I carried on pretending it hadn’t happened to me. <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/22/steve-walters-andy-woodward-crewe-alexandra">Steve Walters, another of my old Crewe mates, was next</a> and, though it hit me like a ton of bricks, I still couldn’t bring myself to admit straight away I was another one. It’s only now, after an awful lot of soul-searching, that I feel strong enough to do it. But it’s tough, really tough. It isn’t easy admitting you were one of Barry Bennell’s boys.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/16/crewe-barry-bennell-micky-fallon">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/football/football">Football</category>

      <description><p>Mark Hazeldine was a star of the Manchester City youth set-up but his behaviour changed dramatically after he went on a trip to Spain alone with Bennell. In 2006 he took his own life</p><p>It doesn’t take long, listening to the stories about Mark Hazeldine, to understand why there are still people involved in football today who find it difficult to understand how someone with his rare talent could be lost to the sport.</p><p>Mark played for one of the junior teams affiliated to Manchester City, the club he grew up supporting. Blue Star FC even wore the red and black stripes that Malcolm Allison, City’s assistant manager, introduced in the 1960s, inspired by the great Milan sides.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/16/barry-bennell-manchester-city-mark-hazeldine-killed-himself">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Chelsea’s hopes of upsetting Barcelona rest on Belgian but he may wonder if his best chance of achieving greatness is to move</p><p>This week <a href="https://twitter.com/ebuka_akara/status/963681678416863232">a clip emerged of three Barcelona players being confronted by a metal railing</a>, with each of them choosing to deal with the obstacle in a different way.       <title>Alex McLeish getting Scotland job stems from blind panic and lack of foresight | Ewan Murray</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2018/feb/16/alex-mcleish-scotland-scottish-fa</link>
      <description>Scottish FA’s failings are exposed by decision to bring in McLeish from the cold to manage the team for a second time<p>Any search for ill will towards Alex McLeish within Scottish football would be a tough one. Although unanimous sentiment towards football managers is an impossibility, those who have dealt professionally with the 59-year-old will generally report on a thoroughly decent, charismatic, clued-up individual. McLeish’s knowledge of global football is understated and an exception to the notion that detail is the domain of younger coaches.</p><p>McLeish has 77 Scotland caps. When faced with downsizing at Rangers he returned seven trophies – including a domestic treble – and progress to the last 16 of the Champions League. Success with Birmingham preceded as bizarre a managerial move in 2011 as it looks today: to Aston Villa.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2018/feb/16/alex-mcleish-scotland-scottish-fa">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Gordon Taylor is paid four times sum of benevolent grants to former players | David Conn</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/16/gordon-taylor-salary-four-times-benevolent-grants-former-players-pfa</link>
      <description>PFA chief executive was paid £2.29m last year while grants to those ill, infirm, in poverty or with mental conditions totalled £530,000<p>The annual unveiling of the salary paid to Gordon Taylor has become a ritual of public bewilderment, a surfacing of dysfunctional relationships embedded in a flourishing sport. This time the gasps were for <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/12/pfa-gordon-taylor-pressure-scandalous-salary" title="">£2.29m paid last year to the 73-year-old</a>, who is the chief executive – since 1981 – of the Professional Footballers’ Association, which is still constituted as an actual trade union.</p><p>Given the PFA’s distinguished past battling to overturn players’ oppressive pay and conditions, it is customarily noted that Taylor takes home very much more money than the chief executive of any other trade union. The Professional Cricketers’ Association paid its chief executive, David Leatherdale, £137,990 last year; the Rugby Players’ Association in England paid <a href="https://therpa.co.uk/about-us/the-rpa-team-2/" title="">Damian Hopley</a> £134,430.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/16/gordon-taylor-salary-four-times-benevolent-grants-former-players-pfa">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Graham Potter is the English manager who took Arsenal's Europa League opponents Östersund from the fourth tier of Swedish football to the top flight in only five years. Increasingly bored by the formulaic coaching that defined his life as a professional, Potter completed an Open University degree in social sciences while still playing.     <item>
      <title>Inside the Sporting Lisbon academy, where Ballon d'Or winners are made</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/in-bed-with-maradona/2018/feb/16/sporting-lisbon-academy-ronaldo-figo-ballon-dor</link>
      <description><p>Sporting have developed Cristiano Ronaldo, Luís Figo and eight of the 11 players who started for Portugal in the Euro 2016 final</p><p>By <a href="https://twitter.com/alexclapham">Alex Clapham</a> for <a href="http://inbedwithmaradona.com/">In Bed With Maradona</a></p><p>“Effort, Dedication, Devotion, Glory.” Those are the first and last words the young hopefuls see as they enter and leave the Sporting Clube de Portugal academy. I had visited <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/these-football-times/2018/jan/11/benfica-academy-world-football-transfers">Benfica’s €15m complex the night before</a> and was immediately struck by the contrasting values at this rural complex in Alcochete. Perhaps it was the €0.40 coffee served to me in the clubhouse by a bronzed pensioner who was wearing a permanent scowl. Without extravagances, this is a place for football.</p><p>As coaches gathered around a portable TV to watch Primeira Liga highlights and plan what the evening would have in store, I couldn’t help but daydream about the players who had walked these corridors and slept in the rooms next door, back when they owned nothing more than a pocketful of ambition. Sporting have produced Portugal’s two most capped players, Cristiano Ronaldo and Luís Figo, both of whom have won the Ballon d’Or, the Champions League and a shedload of leagues and cups. There are signed pictures and murals of the pair plastered all around the facilities.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/in-bed-with-maradona/2018/feb/16/sporting-lisbon-academy-ronaldo-figo-ballon-dor">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Anonymous letters and threats: How racism came to stalk US youth soccer</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/15/us-youth-soccer-racism</link>
      <description><p>For players as young as eight on Idaho’s Juniors FC, the possibility of abuse when they step on the field is very real. And they are from from unique</p><p>Jeromy Tarkon, a youth soccer coach in Boise, Idaho, walked out to his car on a Sunday morning this past January and discovered a plastic-wrapped letter sitting on its windshield. “It’s because of liberals like you,” the letter began, “that our state is full of nigers [sic] and wetbacks.”<br><br>The anonymous letter writer said one young black player on Tarkon’s club team, Juniors FC, had “made the field unclean when he stepped on it,” and how, if he wasn’t careful, Tarkon himself might one day soon “piss off the wrong parent or families”.<br><br>Tarkon, a white military veteran originally from California, could have accepted a personal attack, but racially abusing the eight- and nine-year-old children on his team was more abuse than he was willing to tolerate.<br><br>After consulting with his assistant coaches – all of whom come from immigrant backgrounds – Tarkon decided to <a href="https://www.facebook.com/idahojuniorsfc/posts/1392441384199152">publish the letter on the team’s Facebook page</a> and go public with the story.<br><br>Tarkon’s team, though, had been the victim of racial abuse before. In one incident last year, Juniors FC players were taunted by the parents from an opposing team as they walked out onto the field for a game. “Here come the future convicts,” some parents shouted loud enough for the Juniors FC coaches to hear. “Watch out for your wallets.” In two other separate incidents, Tarkon says that he has heard parents from opposing teams aim the n-word at his players.<br><br>Tarkon had previously believed that comments like these weren’t worth reporting to the Idaho Youth Soccer Association (IYSA), the state’s governing body and the only institution with the power to levy punishments. He and his assistants figured that their players could respond with their play on the field and that, if the incident was bad enough, they could work something out with the club of the offending party, a process outlined in the IYSA’s policies.<br><br>“Maybe I haven’t been proactive enough and the reason why is I know we don’t want to get people more mad than they already are,” Tarkon told the Guardian.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/jun/01/us-soccer-diversity-problem-world-football">'It’s only working for the white kids': American soccer's diversity problem</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/15/us-youth-soccer-racism">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Toulouse's fear of relegation is harming their talented young players</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/12/toulouse-ligue-1-relegation-young-players-psg-marseille</link>
      <description><p>Toulouse should be developing their academy products instead of signing Premier League misfits such as Yaya Sanogo</p><p>By <a href="https://twitter.com/FRfootballAdam">Adam White</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/ericdevin_">Eric Devin</a> for <a href="http://www.getfootballnewsfrance.com/">Get French Football News</a></p><p>Things were supposed to improve for Toulouse when they dismissed Pascal Dupraz a few weeks ago but their struggles continued on Saturday with a 1-0 defeat to Paris Saint-Germain. Despite putting in a spirited performance at the Stade Municipal against the league leaders, the outlook remains bleak. Even their two 1-0 victories were underwhelming – it is hard to take much solace from beating a Nice side torn apart by injury and a Troyes team who were forced to play nearly the entire match with 10 men – and their most striking result of recent weeks was the 2-0 defeat to Ligue 2 strugglers Bourg-en-Bresse that handed them an embarrassing elimination from the Coupe de France.</p><p>Dupraz’s fiery personality and skill as a motivator helped the team avoid relegation in 2016 but he has struggled to develop a talented group of players. Highly touted players such as Issa Diop, Alexis Blin, Yann Bodiger and Kelvin Amian are no further along than they were 18 months ago, having been stymied by inconsistent tactics and a lack of discipline. This charge cannot be levelled at the club’s teenage goalkeeper, Alban Lafont, who played a blinder on Saturday, but he seems to be the exception who proves the rule.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/12/toulouse-ligue-1-relegation-young-players-psg-marseille">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>European roundup: Real Madrid go third thanks to Cristiano Ronaldo hat-trick</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/10/european-roundup-real-madrid-real-sociedad-cristiano-ronaldo-hat-trick</link>
      <description>• Real beat Real Socieded 5-2; second-placed Atlético beat Málaga<br />• Robert Lewandowski equals record as Bayern go 18 points clear<p>Cristiano Ronaldo scored a hat-trick as <strong>Real Madrid</strong> moved into third place following a 5-2 thumping of <strong>Real Sociedad</strong> at the Bernabéu. Ronaldo set up Lucas Vázquez for his first-minute opener before going on to add the second himself just before the half-hour mark.</p><p>Toni Kroos fired Real’s third in the 34th minute with Ronaldo notching his second – and the hosts’ fourth – three minutes later. Jon Bautista pulled one back for Sociedad in the 74th minute but Ronaldo was again on target 10 minutes from the final whistle. Asier Illarramendi added the visitors’ second in the 83rd minute but it was too little, too late.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/10/european-roundup-real-madrid-real-sociedad-cristiano-ronaldo-hat-trick">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Van Marwijk's Socceroos appointment shows lack of long-term direction</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/12/van-marwijks-socceroos-appointment-shows-lack-of-long-term-direction</link>
      <description><p>The Dutchman has no incentive to invest in the future of Australian football</p><p>Bert van Marwijk made a solid first impression as Socceroos coach last week. He lobbied persuasively for his career to be appraised without such laser beam focus on the notorious <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/jul/12/world-cup-final-johan-cruyff-holland">2010 World Cup final</a>. He spoke knowledgeably about tactics and trends, using specific examples from his stint in Saudi Arabia to illustrate the courage and flexibility of his decision making. But amongst the technical proficiency, Van Marwijk’s visit crystallised the flaws in Football Federation Australia’s appointment. </p><p>The most obvious flaw is Van Marwijk’s nationality. <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jan/08/graham-arnold-is-the-standout-candidate-and-should-already-be-socceroos-coach">The coach of Australia’s national team should be Australian</a>, and some of the consequences of that not being the case can already be felt.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/12/van-marwijks-socceroos-appointment-shows-lack-of-long-term-direction">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>As US Soccer picks a new president, everyone thinks they have the answer</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/09/us-soccer-election-sunil-gulati-candidates</link>
      <description><p>Sunil Gulati’s successor will be elected this weekend in Orlando and ideas to secure a permanent place in the world’s elite are flying back and forth</p><p>The US Soccer Federation has nearly $150m in the bank, up from roughly $6.6m at the turn of the century. The federation is not hoarding – spending has roughly tripled over that same time span – and it has legions of youth players: somewhere between 3.5 million and 4 million registered and millions more unregistered, even in the <a href="http://www.engagesports.com/blog/post/1488/youth-sports-participation-statistics-and-trends">gloomy surveys showing kids turning away from sports</a>.</p><p>What it does not have is a berth at the 2018 World Cup finals. Nor does it have youth teams that qualify for tournaments as consistently as they used to. Even the mighty US women’s team isn’t as mighty as it once was, following up its first failure to medal in a major international event (the 2016 Olympics) with a bunch of losses.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/09/us-soccer-election-sunil-gulati-candidates">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Barry Bennell: the predatory Pied Piper who made stars and shattered lives</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/15/barry-bennell-abuse-manchester-city-crewe</link>
      <description><p>The former Manchester City and Crewe coach exploited his status to abuse potentially hundreds of boys, employing gifts, a sheep’s head and haunted houses to subject his victims to unspeakable horrors</p><p>Andy Woodward, one of the boys lost and brutalised during Barry Bennell’s decades of preying on young footballers, can remember one story that probably helps to explain why the detectives investigating the man described as a “child molester on an industrial scale” believe the true number of victims will be incalculable.</p><p>Bennell had taken a group of Crewe Alexandra players to Florida in the summer of 1990 to help with a series of junior coaching courses. He had hired jet-skis and was out in the sea at Pensacola beach, with an 11-year-old on the back, when he fell into the water. He was climbing back on board when Craig Hignett, the first-team striker, came past on his own jet-ski and turned to spray him. Except Hignett also lost control of his machine.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/15/barry-bennell-abuse-manchester-city-crewe">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Neymar wilts in Madrid as superclub tie descends into Disneyfied dystopia | Jonathan Wilson</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/15/neymar-cristiano-ronaldo-psg-real-madrid-champions-league-super-clubs</link>
      <description><p>The Brazilian repeatedly ran down blind alleys as PSG appeared incoherent in the face of Real and Cristiano Ronaldo’s efficiency</p><p>Two superclubs! The most successful club in European history! The other a club that has just arranged the two most expensive transfers in history! Cristiano Ronaldo v Neymar, the ageing great against the rising star! Skill! Tricks! Flair! Late drama! Rabonas, backheels, dribbles! There was plenty to watch in <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/14/real-madrid-paris-saint-germain-champions-league-last-16-first-leg-match-report">Real Madrid’s win over Paris Saint-Germain on Wednesday</a>, plenty of story and plenty of spectacle, but there was also a sense of the emperor’s new clothes to the whole affair. The actual football wasn’t very good.</p><p>There was plenty of fine individual skill, for sure, plenty that could be cropped and gif-ed, but there was very little in the way of cohesion. This was a film executive’s idea of football, a game that called to mind the fact Real Madrid’s director general, José Angel Sánchez, has said the club sees Disney as its model. It was full of screams and dives and needless flourishes, a mess of individuals in desperate need of structure, self-absorbed and self-indulgent.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/15/neymar-cristiano-ronaldo-psg-real-madrid-champions-league-super-clubs">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Liverpool’s Henderson and Milner provide base for front line’s fireworks | Ben Fisher</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2018/feb/15/liverpool-henderson-milner-porto-champions-league</link>
      <description><p>Jürgen Klopp’s team struck the perfect balance in Porto with Jordan Henderson and James Milner assuming midfield control and Sadio Mané profiting from their dominance</p><p>How many will Mohamed Salah get this season? Forty? Fifty? A tired puff of the cheeks by Porto’s Moussa Marega after his irresistible 30th said it all. There was half an hour on the clock inside the Estádio do Dragão when Salah opened his tally for the evening. Liverpool supporters idolise the man they call the Egyptian King but Salah seems to have grander plans, like conquering Europe, for starters. Salah provided the delicate touches on a night when Liverpool displayed an iron core and just what their manager, Jürgen Klopp, had requested – “a real serious performance”.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/14/porto-liverpool-champions-league-last-16-first-leg-match-report">Sadio Mané’s stunning hat-trick inspires Liverpool stroll against Porto</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2018/feb/15/liverpool-henderson-milner-porto-champions-league">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/16/football-transfer-rumours-manchester-uniteds-paul-pogba-to-real-madrid</link>
      <description><p>Today’s fluff just toss that ham in the fryin’ pan</p><p>In devastating news for <strong>Manchester United</strong> fans, it seems that one of their top midfielders is likely to leave this summer. Get the emotional tributes ready as soon as possible because there are reports in Turkey that <strong>Marouane Fellaini</strong> has agreed a contract with <strong>Besiktas</strong>. Don’t all cry at once. Oh, and <strong>Paul Pogba</strong> is also off. The Frenchman will join <strong>Real Madrid</strong> for £120m after deciding that José Mourinho ain’t worth it. United will console themselves by signing <strong>Mauro Icardi</strong> from <strong>Internazionale</strong>. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/15/tottenham-erik-lamela-contract-extend">Tottenham have option to extend Érik Lamela’s contract by a further year</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/16/football-transfer-rumours-manchester-uniteds-paul-pogba-to-real-madrid">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Footballers joining and leaving a club soon after | The Knowledge</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/14/footballers-joining-and-leaving-a-club-in-the-same-transfer-window-the-knowledge</link>
      <description><p>Plus: extreme weather at the very first MLS Cup and winning the FA Cup the hard way. <a href="mailto:knowledge@theguardian.com">Mail us your questions and answers</a> or tweet <a href="https://twitter.com/theknowledge_gu">@TheKnowledge_GU</a></p><p><strong>“Scott Bain signed for Hibs on loan on the first day of the window and left for Celtic on the last day. Have any other players ever joined and left a club in the same window?”</strong> tweets Brian Milne.</p><p>The answer, of course, is yes. In the summer of 1980, Clive Allen joined Arsenal from QPR for a fee of £1.25m. He played in three friendlies before joining Crystal Palace’s team of the 80s, in a swap deal which sent Kenny Sansom and his Norman Wisdom impressions in the opposite direction. Ostend Gudgeon reckons this became a Newman-Baddiel running gag, “probably in the Mary Whitehouse Experience”. <br tabindex="-1"></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/14/footballers-joining-and-leaving-a-club-in-the-same-transfer-window-the-knowledge">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Joy of Six: Aston Villa v Birmingham City memories | Scott Murray</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2018/feb/08/the-joy-of-six-aston-villa-v-birmingham-city-memories</link>
      <description><p>Bitter rivalry, free-scoring marksmen, stretchers, rage and Peter Enckelman: half a dozen Second City derby stories</p><p>Villa dominated the Football League during its Victorian infancy – they racked up five titles by 1900 – so their early command of the Birmingham scene is no great surprise. In November 1887, they met the club that would become bitter city rivals in serious competition for the first time: Small Heath Alliance were dispatched 4-0 in the FA Cup second round. It was payback for the first friendly between the clubs in 1879, which Alliance won 1-0 at their Muntz Street ground. Villa – already a grand, bordering on aristocratic, institution despite being just four years and nine months old – complained bitterly that the pitch was full of holes.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2018/feb/08/the-joy-of-six-aston-villa-v-birmingham-city-memories">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sky and BT are paying less but the Premier League bubble has not burst</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/14/premier-league-bubble-not-bursting-tv-rights-sky-bt-sport</link>
      <description>Broadcasters are saving under the latest TV rights deal but it does not look like the beginning of the end for the money feast<p>An assessment of the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/13/sky-bt-sport-premier-league-tv-rights" title="">near-£4.5bn committed to Premier League clubs</a> for live UK televising of their matches from 2019‑22 can be assisted by adapting a famous old quip: reports of football’s bubble bursting are greatly exaggerated.</p><p>True, this £4.464bn to 20 football clubs, on which Sky and BT Sport will aim to make profits by charging supporters subscriptions, is approximately £500m less than the record £5.13bn the two broadcasters paid last time for the 2016-19 rights. But it does not look like the beginning of the end for the money feast for clubs, their owners, managers, players and agents, which they have been served up for 25 years by making supporters pay to watch football on television.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/14/premier-league-bubble-not-bursting-tv-rights-sky-bt-sport">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>It’s time to ignore the sceptics and take delight in this Tottenham team | Barney Ronay</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/14/tottenham-hotspur-delight-champions-league-juventus</link>
      <description>While the doom merchants point out they have yet to win anything, most fans would like to see their own team built, and play, like Mauricio Pochettino’s<p>The last time a Premier League team produced a stirring two-goal comeback in Turin was in 1999 when the world was still young, when the current managers of Chelsea, Real Madrid and France were playing for <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KHun70cat14" title="">Juventus, and when a Manchester United team</a> with an armature of homegrown talent gave post-Heysel English football its first really compelling European story.</p><p>The comparison with <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/13/juventus-tottenham-hotspur-champions-league-match-report" title="">Tottenham’s stirring 2-2 draw</a> at the Allianz Stadium on Tuesday goes only so far. Which is, in reality, not very far at all. There was a tempting little mnemonic in the angle of Tottenham’s comeback goal, the way Harry Kane cut the ball across into the far corner from the left, drawing an echo of Roy Keane’s flicked near-post header with United also 2-0 down, a moment of footballing Madeleine cake washing about in a silver teaspoon of grainy old YouTube highlights’ films.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/14/tottenham-hotspur-delight-champions-league-juventus">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>When Arsenal showed France tough love on Valentine's Day</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/that-1980s-sports-blog/2018/feb/14/france-arsenal-world-cup-qualifier-scotland-valentines-day</link>
      <description><p>Michel Platini thought playing a ‘very British’ Arsenal team at Highbury would prepare France for a World Cup qualifier in Scotland, but the plan backfired. France lost both matches 2-0</p><p>By <a href="https://twitter.com/1980ssportsblog">Steven Pye</a> for <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/that-1980s-sports-blog">That 1980s Sports Blog</a></p><p>It’s hard to imagine Arsenal being in the title race in February and then adding an extra fixture against a national football team to their schedule. It wouldn’t happen these days but in 1989 George Graham’s team took a break from their pursuit of the championship to do Michel Platini a favour.</p><p>The France manager needed all the help he could get after a stuttering start to their qualifying campaign for the 1990 World Cup. France beat Norway 1-0 in their first qualifier thanks to an 84th-minute penalty from Jean-Pierre Papin but only could only draw in Cyprus before losing to Yugoslavia. With a difficult trip to Scotland on the horizon, Platini came up with the plan of playing a British club side to prepare his men for the challenge ahead.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/that-1980s-sports-blog/2018/feb/14/france-arsenal-world-cup-qualifier-scotland-valentines-day">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Matty Fryatt: ‘I was coming off the training pitch nearly crying, in agony’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/08/matty-fryatt-retires-nottingham-forest-hull-achilles-injury</link>
      <description><p>Striker who played for Hull in 2014 FA Cup final is retiring aged 31 because of an achilles injury sustained at Nottingham Forest</p><p>There were times over the past three years when Matty Fryatt felt “like a car on the driveway, rusting away”. He talks about being “lost and forgotten” at Nottingham Forest, where he battled to overcome an achilles injury that led to three operations and plenty of soul‑searching as he kept asking himself when he would ever get the chance to return to the pitch. The answer, Fryatt decided this week, is&nbsp;never.</p><p>After travelling all over Europe in search of a cure, undergoing surgery that he regrets, fighting back tears on the training ground and feeling embarrassed that he was simply unable to run, Fryatt has come to the conclusion that enough is enough and used this interview to announce his retirement from professional football at the age of 31.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/08/matty-fryatt-retires-nottingham-forest-hull-achilles-injury">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sky netted a sweet Premier League deal but the TV rights bubble isn’t over</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/sky-premier-league-tv-rights-deal-amazon-on-sidelines</link>
      <description>The value of TV packages may have plateaued in the UK but footie bosses aren’t worried, with the game’s appeal growing globally and the likes of Amazon on the sidelines<p>On the face of it, the outcome of the latest battle for <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/13/sky-bt-sport-premier-league-tv-rights" title="">Premier League TV rights</a> appears to be business as usual. Sky has taken the lion’s share of the best matches, extending its stranglehold on the biggest prize in British sports broadcasting to at least three decades, with BT slotting into second place.</p><p>But with Amazon in the running for at least one of the two remaining rights packages, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/feb/12/rupert-murdoch-pledge-keep-sky-news-independent-fox-takeover" title="">Rupert Murdoch poised to take full control of Sky</a> and then <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/jan/27/drama-for-sky-and-disney-as-rivals-enter-arena" title="">sell it to Disney</a>, and BT calling time on its big spending on sports rights, it is a seminal moment.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/sky-premier-league-tv-rights-deal-amazon-on-sidelines">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Huddersfield Town v Manchester United: FA Cup – as it happened</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/feb/17/huddersfield-town-v-manchester-united-fa-cup-live</link>
      <description><p>Romelu Lukaku scored twice for Manchester United as they beat Huddersfield, despite a Juan Mata goal being disallowed in a confusing VAR moment</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2018-02-17T19:34:59.227Z">7.34pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>VAR was a distraction here, and I hope that the confusion that surrounded the end of the first half doesn’t unfairly occupy the headlines. It was a mess, without a doubt, but it seems the decision was ultimately correct and the big problem seems to have been the wiggly lines that somehow made their way to the broadcasters. </p><p>Let’s concentrate on the actual football, though, which was entertaining, if only sporadically outstanding. Huddersfield fought hard, and played their way through midfield well, but their final delivery simply wasn’t good enough. Time and again they made it as far as the United defence but no further, with Smalling in particular winning countless headers and flinging his limbs in the way of various passes and shots. United were outfought and outplayed in midfield, but had the cutting edge at one end and the concentration and determination at the other. They had few chances, and only two shots on target, but that’s all they needed.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/huddersfield-manchester-united-fa-cup-match-report">Manchester United’s Romelu Lukaku turns on power to sink Huddersfield</a> </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2018-02-17T19:26:08.358Z">7.26pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p><strong>90+4 mins:</strong> And that’s it! United weren’t great, but they have won.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/feb/17/huddersfield-town-v-manchester-united-fa-cup-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Manchester United’s Romelu Lukaku sinks Huddersfield despite VAR chaos</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/huddersfield-manchester-united-fa-cup-match-report</link>
      <description><p>Paul Pogba missed this game through illness, leaving Manchester United to book their place in the last eight of the FA Cup without him. Thanks to Romelu Lukaku’s 20th and 21st goals of the season they managed it comfortably enough, the striker showing the value of possessing an accomplished goalscorer when chances are few and far between.</p><p>Huddersfield could have done with a similarly potent spearhead, since for all their attacking intent they came up short in front of goal. With the benefit of an early lead United could afford to be economical, letting their opponents have most of the ball and hitting them effectively on the counter. The visitors were not at their swaggering best, yet the home side ended up grateful to a VAR call at the end of the first half for helping keep the scoreline respectable. “We didn’t get the result we wanted but confidence wise we are going in the right direction,” David Wagner said. “We are building up momentum again.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/huddersfield-manchester-united-fa-cup-match-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Rochdale v Tottenham Hotspur: match preview</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/rochdale-tottenham-hotspur-match-preview</link>
      <description><p>Rochdale are staring relegation full in the face as they sit bottom of League One and are 11 points from safety. There is some hope in having between three and five games in hand on their rivals for the drop and it is a similar glimmer that Keith Hill will cling to against Tottenham. Mauricio Pochettino has apologised for his criticism of the, now relayed, Spotland pitch but his side’s heroics in Turin might not be ideal preparation. Even with a much-changed lineup, including a debut for Lucas Moura, Tottenham should prevail. <strong>Graham Searles</strong></p><p><strong>Sunday</strong> 4pm <em>BBC One</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/17/rochdale-tottenham-hotspur-match-preview">Continue reading...</a></description>
